And so too would have been Battle of the Holy, had they, you know, put it in.

author: fatjoe460

text: IMO this is the best of the 8/16 bit Castlevania's. Tight level design, good bosses, fast pace while still nailing the series emphasis on measured action, and both characters play completely differently. If it had a slightly better final stage (bit of filler with the recycled halls and boss rush), I think it would be superior to Akumajou Dracula x68000.
author: BuyMeThingsNow

text:
I believe the Sharp x68000 game is also 16-bit.
Either way, it's unusual to find someone who shares my opinion that those two Castlevania games are the best of fourth gen.
author: Cheeseman

text: @CheesemanÂ Yeah, both games are really amazing.

text: The genesis' inferior sound card managed to have an interesting tangy sound with music made on it. What came out was some amazing pieces like this.
author: Sovspot

text:
I don't think that the YM2612 is really that inferior to what the SNES had
the SNES only has the advantage of having hardware sample playback and more channels, it lacks any kind of synthesis, unlike the YM2612
author: Toru the Red Fox

text: I really love the music in this game.  I really think its Yamane's second best soundtrack in the series only trailing SOTN imo.  It's a shame that she had to leave Konami, but she continues to make great soundtracks like Skullgirls and others.
author: Eric C.

text: Yamane's first Castlevania soundtrack, numerous of its themes are now considered classics and they got their fair share of remixes. The game itself is very solid, though I found it felt a bit archaic 2 years after Super Castlevania IV introduced great gameplay innovations.
author: SupraDarky

text: Yeah, though the music was still really good, especially coming from the horrendous Sega Genesis sound chip.
author: Aaron Smith

text: @Aaron SmithÂ Not entirely sure if the genesis sound chip was actually bad, or just a result of lazy programming on most developers parts who didn't take full advantage of it. I remember there was a larger story behind this.
author: BuyMeThingsNow

text: @Aaron SmithÂ As this song alone shows, the chip is actually quite versatile, and has quite a beefy sound to it in the right hands. Â Look up some of Hitoshi Sakimoto's Genesis soundtracks: he mastered the chip, and even wrote and licensed his own engine for use in other games. Â Some of the best chiptunes of all the time!
author: Fellshard

text:
@BuyMeThingsNowÂ I'll say it's most likely lazy programming, especially in Western Genesis games *cough* GEMS *cough*. From what Genesis/Megadrive music I've heard, Japanese-made games tend to have better sounding music than their Western counterparts.

My guess is that Japanese developers had access to better tools/documentation of the hardware, while NA/Europe devs were stuck composing with GEMS, which doesn't even utilize the YM2612 sound chip to its fullest potential. But there are a few exceptions where GEMS wasn't used though. For instance, Jesper Kyd composed soundtracks for Sub-Terrania and The Adventures of Batman and Robin using a custom sound driver he wrote and the music for both games are fucking glorious.
author: FMFlameNinja

text: It doesn't really help that it's really hard to make good-sounding synths intuitively with FM synthesis, especially when the feedback loop for composers and sound engineers was probably quite minimal.
author: Fellshard

text: @FellshardÂ  For me FM synthesis have one name: Zun. PC9801 is a good example of what a good FM synthetizer can do. Besides Mega Drive games here in America, had its good games.
author: Kenneth Gonzalez

text: The reason why Western developers used GEMS is because it's what SEGA of America/Europe handed out to them in their dev kits, and so they simply didn't bother making their own. Also, some part of me wants to believe that they didn't know that FM chips could sound any better, given how bad their Sound Blaster/Adlib (YM3812) soundtracks tended to be as well. YM3812 too was capable of much better music than the reputation which preceded it.
author: UsagiJojo

text:
To all of you thrashing on GEMS, it was quite a good engine not even made by SEGA Japan. It allowed you to use the Genesis/Mega Drive for playback and create your own instruments.
It came with built-in instruments for you to start on. Most composers used those instruments as they were and didn't bother to edit them.
There are great western soundtracks for the Genesis like everything Tommy Talarico wrote, the early EA Sports games and Toe Jam an' Earl, etc.

There is a video that delves deeper on the topic called "How Genesis music was made".
author: Ex-Casual
